body:
Addition:
For MySQL, the keywords described [here](http://mysql-python.sourceforge.net/MySQLdb.html#id7) are currently supported as key-value-pairs in the MySQLdb implementation.

rename.from: Feature request: Control pool size of DB connections
rename.to: Feature request: Pass DB connection parameters to SQLAlchemy

body:
@julilien thanks for raising this - would be happy to review a PR that contributes this if you're interested :)

It'd be helpful to first quickly sketch out exactly how we'd allow specifying connection parameters would work - maybe via e.g. an extra `--db-opts` argument to `mlflow server`? Another alternative would be to try putting the parameters in the connection string itself, but this seems likely to get messy & not play well with passing additional args e.g. when running the server from a docker image, etc.

I'd say that `--db-opts` should be the way to go since the connection string itself is processed by the DB engine, such as MySQLdb. By using `--db-opts`, you'd have a clear distinction between parameterizing SQLAlchemy in general and specifically configuring the database's driver engine (e.g. by MySQLdb specific configuration parameters).
@smurching Let me know if you share this opinion. Then I would start working on it. :)
Hi @julilien, yep the `--db-opts` approach seems reasonable to me :)

Also out of curiosity, what's the use case in which you're running hundreds or thousands of jobs in parallel (hyperparam tuning)? Mainly wondering if there's anything else MLflow can do to better support that use case.

Hi @smurching, thanks for your interest. My use case for running that many jobs is to perform experiments for some models on a large set of reference datasets with different seeds. The huge number of jobs is performed to achieve statistical significance in the evaluation. In each job, a hyperparameter optimization is performed. Due to a high runtime of the experiments, a subsequent execution is not feasible.

I analyzed the number of connections opened by every run. Following the default parameterization of the SQLAlchemy engine, a pool size of 5 connections is created at startup. I got at least 10 connections (sometimes closing the connection of former runs takes some time) for each hyperparameter step (5 for the outer run, 5 for the current nested run). I've already increased the maximum number of connections allowed by the database but there are still too many.

I tried different things, incl. trying to reset the connection pool after the engine's creation, but, however, had no success. Is there a way to reuse connections opened by the outer runs using `mlflow.start_run()`?

Ah, it sounds like you might be using e.g. `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("mysql://...")` from within your hyperparameter tuning program? The current behavior of the MLflow fluent Python APIs is indeed to create a new `MlflowClient` (and therefore a new SQLAlchemy engine, if your tracking URI is set to a DB URI like `mysql://...`) on each call to `log_metric`, `start_run`, etc - we do this to allow for dynamically pulling credentials on each function call, e.g. when logging to a remote tracking server. However, if you run the tracking server we create & reuse a single SQLAlchemy engine. Thus one approach could be to run a tracking server with `mlflow server --backend-store-uri mysql://... --default-artifact-root <your-default-artifact-root>` and configure your hyperparam tuning program to log to the server via `mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://your-server's-uri")`. 

I'd be curious to hear if this works for you, but happy to review a contribution making the SQLAlchemy settings configurable either way - thanks!

That sounds reasonable and solved my problem with a huge amount of jobs, thanks for that! :)

Nevertheless, I think it is helpful to configure the SQLAlchemy engine creation in many situations, e.g. for manually fixing the initial connection pool size. Therefore, I'll go for a contribution.

Hi @julilien,

Have you started working on this? I am having problems with a MLFlow tracking server. Need to pass `pool_pre_ping=True` to the SQLAlchemy engine so expired connections are handled and connection failures are not transferred to the client. See: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/core/pooling.html#pool-disconnects

I'm using AWS Aurora and every few hours the server will kill old connections.

Let me know if you need help.

I created a PR for this: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/1635

Could you please take a look @smurching ?
Seems like this has since been resolved (see discussion in https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/1635), closing

@adeandrade 
 how were you able to user aurora and pass its connection details to mlflow ? it would be superhelpful if you could point me to a an example. I am on same boat
